cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who is the owner of the crowne plaza
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
To determine the owner of the Crowne Plaza hotel brand, we need to consider the structure of the hospitality industry. Crowne Plaza is a brand within the InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), which is a multinational hotel company. IHG operates several hotel brands, including Crowne Plaza, Holiday Inn, and InterContinental. Therefore, the ownership of Crowne Plaza falls under the umbrella of IHG. 

Answer: The owner of the Crowne Plaza is InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG).

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who is the owner of the crowne plaza
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['In September 2017, Massachusetts Mutual Life sold the hotel building to a new owner, EOS DCH Owner LLC, for $106.5 million. The hotel disassociated from the Crowne Plaza brand, and became an independent property.\n', "In June 2005, Santander Real's investment fund acquired 50% of the building for €138.6 million, committing to purchase the remaining 50% belonging to the hotel shortly thereafter. The Crowne Plaza Hotel occupying the building closed in 2006. The deal closed in early December 2007. Santander renovated the building, preserving intact the facade and the lobby as part of a project to build a hotel and apartments, but the project stalled in 2010.\n", 'It was sold again in mid-2010 for $47.8m to local company Hargate Properties who retained the affiliation with Crowne Plaza Hotels but the new owners went into receivership in November 2011. The purchase of the hotel by Kevyn Frederick in 2010 later was discovered to be part of a large mortgage fraud in the Edmonton area.\n', 'As investment executive of Optima Ventures, Schochet has presided over the acquisition of a number of properties in Cleveland, Ohio including One Cleveland Center (purchased for $86.3 million in 2008); 55 Public Square (purchased for $34 million); the Huntington Bank Building (purchased for $18.5 million in 2010); and the Penton Media Building. In October 2011, Optima entered its first joint venture, buying the 472-room Crowne Plaza Cleveland City Centre hotel with Sage Hospitality Resources, a hotel developer and manager based in Colorado. In September 2014, Schochet and Chip Marous proposed a $231 million renovation of the Huntington Bank Building, the second largest office building in the city, into a mixed-used facility combining offices, apartments, condominiums and a boutique hotel. In June 2015, Terry Coyne, a commercial real estate broker with Newmark, negotiated and coordinated the sale of the building to Andrew “Avi” Greenbaum, principal of Hudson Holdings, for $22.5 million. Hudson began a $280 million renovation of the building which will feature 550 apartments, a 300-room, high-end hotel, feet of retail, a banquet hall, conference space, and a lobby open to the public.\n', 'In February 2017, Barry Felstead replaced Rowen Craigie as CEO Crown Resorts Melbourne.\n', 'In 2004, the building was sold by the Slovak republic to the Dutch company "Myria Assets" for 425 million Slovak crowns. Today, the hotel is called "Crowne Plaza".\n', 'Encana officially confirmed on June 16, 2008, that Jaume Plensa, an artist most famous for the Crown Fountain in Chicago, had been chosen to complete two major public art installations for the project. The first work, entitled "Wonderland", was unveiled on January 25, 2013, on the south plaza. The second work, entitled "Alberta\'s Dream" is located on the north side and depicts a bronze casting of the artist embracing a living tree.\n', "The Crowne Plaza in Christchurch, New Zealand, originally known as the Parkroyal Hotel, was a hotel of the Crowne Plaza group. Built in 1988 in the north-west corner of Victoria Square after much public protest, as it cut off the first part of Victoria Street, its construction happened at the same time and enabled the substantial redesign of Victoria Square. The building had New Zealand's largest atrium, and was one of the city's largest hotels. The building suffered significant damage in the 2011 Christchurch earthquake and was demolished in April 2012. The Crowne Plaza group has secured a lease in the Forsyth Barr Building at the opposite end of Victoria Square.\n", 'In March 2012, the hotel was sold by the Receiver, David Findling to an unnamed investor who reportedly planned to renovate it and enter into a management agreement with Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts, a division of InterContinental Hotels . The Detroit Metro Convention & Visitors Bureau reported that the purchaser was Mexico-based developer Gabriel Ruiz.\n', 'Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay is owned by the SEA Group. The SEA Group was founded in 1956 and was listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 1973 (SEHK: 0251). The Group has been active in both property investments and developments and have to-date developed or owned over 200 properties development in Hong Kong, Mainland China, Australia, Canada, Indonesia, Japan, New Zealand and United Kingdom – with businesses covering hotel, residential, commercial, industrial sectors and etc. Other hotel projects include the Lizard Island Resort on the Great Barrier Reef, Australia.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To answer the question about the ownership of Crowne Plaza, we need to analyze the provided passages for relevant information regarding ownership and management of Crowne Plaza hotels. Here are the key points extracted from the passages, along with an analysis of their relevance:

1. **EOS DCH Owner LLC**: In September 2017, Massachusetts Mutual Life sold a hotel building to EOS DCH Owner LLC, which then disassociated from the Crowne Plaza brand. This indicates that ownership can change and that some properties may not be affiliated with the Crowne Plaza brand anymore.

2. **Santander Real**: In June 2005, Santander Real's investment fund acquired 50% of a building that housed a Crowne Plaza hotel. This shows that ownership can be shared and that investment funds can play a significant role in hotel ownership.

3. **Hargate Properties**: The hotel was sold in mid-2010 to Hargate Properties, which retained the Crowne Plaza affiliation. This illustrates that ownership can be retained even when the property changes hands.

4. **Optima Ventures and Sage Hospitality Resources**: In October 2011, Optima Ventures, in partnership with Sage Hospitality Resources, acquired the Crowne Plaza Cleveland City Centre hotel. This indicates that hotel ownership can involve joint ventures and partnerships, which is common in the hospitality industry.

5. **Gabriel Ruiz**: In March 2012, a hotel was sold to an unnamed investor who was reportedly Gabriel Ruiz, a Mexico-based developer. This highlights the involvement of international investors in the ownership of Crowne Plaza hotels.

6. **SEA Group**: The Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay is owned by the SEA Group, which has a diverse portfolio in property investments and developments. This shows that specific Crowne Plaza locations can have distinct ownership structures.

### Analysis of the Role of These Contents:

- **Ownership Complexity**: The passages reveal that ownership of Crowne Plaza hotels is complex and can involve various entities, including investment funds, local companies, and international developers. This complexity is important for understanding the broader context of hotel management and ownership.

- **Brand Affiliation**: The disassociation of properties from the Crowne Plaza brand after ownership changes indicates that brand affiliation is not permanent and can be influenced by the strategic decisions of the owners.

- **Investment Dynamics**: The involvement of investment funds and joint ventures suggests that financial considerations play a significant role in hotel ownership, which can affect the management and operational strategies of the hotels.

- **Geographical Diversity**: The mention of various owners across different locations (e.g., Hong Kong, Cleveland, Detroit) highlights the global nature of the hospitality industry and the potential for diverse ownership structures based on regional market conditions.

In summary, the passages provide a nuanced understanding of the ownership landscape of Crowne Plaza hotels, illustrating that ownership can vary widely and is influenced by multiple factors, including investment strategies, brand management, and geographical considerations. This background is essential for answering questions about specific ownership of Crowne Plaza properties.

To determine the owner of the Crowne Plaza brand, we must first recognize that Crowne Plaza is part of the InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), a multinational hotel company that operates various hotel brands. However, the ownership of individual Crowne Plaza properties can vary significantly, as ownership may be held by different entities, including investment funds, local companies, and international developers.

1. **InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG)**: As the parent company, IHG owns the Crowne Plaza brand and is responsible for its overall management and marketing. This means that while IHG owns the brand, individual hotels may have different owners.

The owner of the Crowne Plaza brand is InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG). However, individual Crowne Plaza hotels may have different owners, including various investment funds and local or international developers, which can lead to changes in brand affiliation over time.

Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:
To determine the owner of the Crowne Plaza brand, we must first recognize that Crowne Plaza is a brand within the InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), a major player in the global hospitality industry. IHG manages a diverse portfolio of hotel brands, including Crowne Plaza, Holiday Inn, and InterContinental, among others. 

However, it is important to note that individual Crowne Plaza hotels may have different ownership structures. Ownership can change due to various factors, including sales, investments, and management agreements. For example, some Crowne Plaza hotels have been sold to different entities, such as EOS DCH Owner LLC and Hargate Properties, which indicates that while the brand is owned by IHG, the physical properties may be owned by various investors or companies.

Additionally, the hotel industry often involves complex relationships between ownership and management. Some properties may operate under the Crowne Plaza brand while being owned by independent investors or real estate firms. This means that while IHG owns the brand itself, the actual ownership of specific Crowne Plaza hotels can vary widely.

Understanding the geographical diversity of Crowne Plaza hotels is also crucial. They are located in various regions, including the United States, New Zealand, and Hong Kong, which can influence ownership dynamics and management strategies based on local market conditions.

In summary, the ownership of the Crowne Plaza brand is held by IHG, but the ownership of individual hotels can differ significantly, reflecting the fluid nature of the hospitality industry.

### Answer:
The owner of the Crowne Plaza brand is InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG). However, individual Crowne Plaza hotels may be owned by various entities, as ownership can change due to sales and investments, while the brand itself remains under IHG's management.

To determine the owner of the Crowne Plaza brand, we must first understand the structure of the hospitality industry and the specific ownership dynamics associated with Crowne Plaza hotels. Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.

The Crowne Plaza Hotel occupying the building closed in 2006. The deal closed in early December 2007. Santander renovated the building, preserving intact the facade and the lobby as part of a project to build a hotel and apartments, but the project stalled in 2010.\n", 'It was sold again in mid-2010 for $47.8m to local company Hargate Properties who retained the affiliation with Crowne Plaza Hotels but the new owners went into receivership in November 2011. The purchase of the hotel by Kevyn Frederick in 2010 later was discovered to be part of a large mortgage fraud in the Edmonton area.\n', 'As investment executive of Optima Ventures, Schochet has presided over the acquisition of a number of properties in Cleveland, Ohio including One Cleveland Center (purchased for $86.3 million in 2008); 55 Public Square (purchased for $34 million); the Huntington Bank Building (purchased for $18.5 million in 2010); and the Penton Media Building. In October 2011, Optima entered its first joint venture, buying the 472-room Crowne Plaza Cleveland City Centre hotel with Sage Hospitality Resources, a hotel developer and manager based in Colorado. In September 2014, Schochet and Chip Marous proposed a $231 million renovation of the Huntington Bank Building, the second largest office building in the city, into a mixed-used facility combining offices, apartments, condominiums and a boutique hotel. In June 2015, Terry Coyne, a commercial real estate broker with Newmark, negotiated and coordinated the sale of the building to Andrew “Avi” Greenbaum, principal of Hudson Holdings, for $22.5 million. Hudson began a $280 million renovation of the building which will feature 550 apartments, a 300-room, high-end hotel, feet of retail, a banquet hall, conference space, and a lobby open to the public.\n', 'In February 2017, Barry Felstead replaced Rowen Craigie as CEO Crown Resorts Melbourne.\n', 'In 2004, the building was sold by the Slovak republic to the Dutch company "Myria Assets" for 425 million Slovak crowns. Today, the hotel is called "Crowne Plaza".\n', 'Encana officially confirmed on June 16, 2008, that Jaume Plensa, an artist most famous for the Crown Fountain in Chicago, had been chosen to complete two major public art installations for the project. The first work, entitled "Wonderland", was unveiled on January 25, 2013, on the south plaza. The second work, entitled "Alberta\'s Dream" is located on the north side and depicts a bronze casting of the artist embracing a living tree.\n', "The Crowne Plaza in Christchurch, New Zealand, originally known as the Parkroyal Hotel, was a hotel of the Crowne Plaza group. Built in 1988 in the north-west corner of Victoria Square after much public protest, as it cut off the first part of Victoria Street, its construction happened at the same time and enabled the substantial redesign of Victoria Square. The building had New Zealand's largest atrium, and was one of the city's largest hotels. The building suffered significant damage in the 2011 Christchurch earthquake and was demolished in April 2012. The Crowne Plaza group has secured a lease in the Forsyth Barr Building at the opposite end of Victoria Square.\n", 'In March 2012, the hotel was sold by the Receiver, David Findling to an unnamed investor who reportedly planned to renovate it and enter into a management agreement with Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts, a division of InterContinental Hotels . The Detroit Metro Convention & Visitors Bureau reported that the purchaser was Mexico-based developer Gabriel Ruiz.\n', 'Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay is owned by the SEA Group. The SEA Group was founded in 1956 and was listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 1973 (SEHK: 0251). The Group has been active in both property investments and developments and have to-date developed or owned over 200 properties development in Hong Kong, Mainland China, Australia, Canada, Indonesia, Japan, New Zealand and United Kingdom – with businesses covering hotel, residential, commercial, industrial sectors and etc. Other hotel projects include the Lizard Island Resort on the Great Barrier Reef, Australia.\n']

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

To determine the ownership of the Crowne Plaza hotel brand, we must consider both the overarching structure of the hospitality industry and the specific ownership details of individual properties. Crowne Plaza is indeed a brand within the InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG), which is a multinational hotel company that operates several hotel brands, including Crowne Plaza, Holiday Inn, and InterContinental. Therefore, the brand itself is owned by IHG.

However, it is crucial to recognize that ownership of specific Crowne Plaza properties can vary significantly. The retrieved passages indicate that:

1. **Ownership Changes**: The ownership of Crowne Plaza hotels can change frequently. For instance, some hotels may be sold to different investors who may choose to retain or disassociate from the Crowne Plaza brand. This suggests that while IHG owns the brand, individual hotel ownership can vary.

2. **Specific Ownership Examples**: 
   - The **Crowne Plaza in Christchurch, New Zealand**, was originally known as the Parkroyal Hotel and was part of the Crowne Plaza group. It suffered significant damage in the 2011 earthquake and was demolished in 2012, indicating challenges faced by the brand.
   - The **Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay** is owned by the SEA Group, highlighting that not all Crowne Plaza properties are owned by IHG or its subsidiaries.

3. **Disassociation from the Brand**: Some properties that were once part of the Crowne Plaza brand may disassociate and become independent hotels, which is essential for understanding the current status of specific locations.

4. **Investment and Renovation Plans**: Various investment groups have acquired Crowne Plaza properties and may plan renovations, indicating ongoing changes in management and ownership that can affect the brand's reputation and operational strategy.

In summary, while the Crowne Plaza brand is owned by IHG, the ownership of individual Crowne Plaza hotels can vary, with some being owned by different investors or companies. This nuanced understanding is critical for accurately representing the ownership landscape of Crowne Plaza hotels.

**Answer:**
The owner of the Crowne Plaza brand is InterContinental Hotels Group (IHG). However, ownership of individual Crowne Plaza hotels can vary. For example, the Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay is owned by the SEA Group, and some properties may disassociate from the brand entirely. Therefore, while IHG owns the Crowne Plaza brand, specific hotels may have different ownership structures.

question_info.question: who is the owner of the crowne plaza
passages:
In September 2017, Massachusetts Mutual Life sold the hotel building to a new owner, EOS DCH Owner LLC, for $106.5 million. The hotel disassociated from the Crowne Plaza brand, and became an independent property.
In June 2005, Santander Real's investment fund acquired 50% of the building for €138.6 million, committing to purchase the remaining 50% belonging to the hotel shortly thereafter. The Crowne Plaza Hotel occupying the building closed in 2006. The deal closed in early December 2007. Santander renovated the building, preserving intact the facade and the lobby as part of a project to build a hotel and apartments, but the project stalled in 2010.
It was sold again in mid-2010 for $47.8m to local company Hargate Properties who retained the affiliation with Crowne Plaza Hotels but the new owners went into receivership in November 2011. The purchase of the hotel by Kevyn Frederick in 2010 later was discovered to be part of a large mortgage fraud in the Edmonton area.
As investment executive of Optima Ventures, Schochet has presided over the acquisition of a number of properties in Cleveland, Ohio including One Cleveland Center (purchased for $86.3 million in 2008); 55 Public Square (purchased for $34 million); the Huntington Bank Building (purchased for $18.5 million in 2010); and the Penton Media Building. In October 2011, Optima entered its first joint venture, buying the 472-room Crowne Plaza Cleveland City Centre hotel with Sage Hospitality Resources, a hotel developer and manager based in Colorado. In September 2014, Schochet and Chip Marous proposed a $231 million renovation of the Huntington Bank Building, the second largest office building in the city, into a mixed-used facility combining offices, apartments, condominiums and a boutique hotel. In June 2015, Terry Coyne, a commercial real estate broker with Newmark, negotiated and coordinated the sale of the building to Andrew “Avi” Greenbaum, principal of Hudson Holdings, for $22.5 million. Hudson began a $280 million renovation of the building which will feature 550 apartments, a 300-room, high-end hotel, feet of retail, a banquet hall, conference space, and a lobby open to the public.
In February 2017, Barry Felstead replaced Rowen Craigie as CEO Crown Resorts Melbourne.
In 2004, the building was sold by the Slovak republic to the Dutch company "Myria Assets" for 425 million Slovak crowns. Today, the hotel is called "Crowne Plaza".
Encana officially confirmed on June 16, 2008, that Jaume Plensa, an artist most famous for the Crown Fountain in Chicago, had been chosen to complete two major public art installations for the project. The first work, entitled "Wonderland", was unveiled on January 25, 2013, on the south plaza. The second work, entitled "Alberta's Dream" is located on the north side and depicts a bronze casting of the artist embracing a living tree.
The Crowne Plaza in Christchurch, New Zealand, originally known as the Parkroyal Hotel, was a hotel of the Crowne Plaza group. Built in 1988 in the north-west corner of Victoria Square after much public protest, as it cut off the first part of Victoria Street, its construction happened at the same time and enabled the substantial redesign of Victoria Square. The building had New Zealand's largest atrium, and was one of the city's largest hotels. The building suffered significant damage in the 2011 Christchurch earthquake and was demolished in April 2012. The Crowne Plaza group has secured a lease in the Forsyth Barr Building at the opposite end of Victoria Square.
In March 2012, the hotel was sold by the Receiver, David Findling to an unnamed investor who reportedly planned to renovate it and enter into a management agreement with Crowne Plaza Hotels & Resorts, a division of InterContinental Hotels . The Detroit Metro Convention & Visitors Bureau reported that the purchaser was Mexico-based developer Gabriel Ruiz.
Crowne Plaza Hong Kong Causeway Bay is owned by the SEA Group. The SEA Group was founded in 1956 and was listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 1973 (SEHK: 0251). The Group has been active in both property investments and developments and have to-date developed or owned over 200 properties development in Hong Kong, Mainland China, Australia, Canada, Indonesia, Japan, New Zealand and United Kingdom – with businesses covering hotel, residential, commercial, industrial sectors and etc. Other hotel projects include the Lizard Island Resort on the Great Barrier Reef, Australia.
